content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; triage meeting will take place in about 1h40
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins:

  • WG-rls2.0 by @matklad
  • WG-self-profile by @mw and @Wesley Wiser
Nothing to report for @WG-self-profile, right @Wesley Wiser?
No, I can't think of anything new since the last check-in
hi @T-compiler/meeting , time for our weekly triage meeting! add a :wave: to show you're here!
thanks very much to @apiraino and @WG-prioritization for preparing today's agenda

We'll start off with ~6 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow we have our monthly planning meeting at 2022-03-04T15:00:00+01:00 (Zulip topic)
@matklad will not be able to provide a check-in this week either to the best of my knowledge.
get your proposals in for the planning meeting! I know there's people champing at the bit to talk about queries and incr-comp, as evidenced by #t-compiler > future of incremental compilation

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
• Signal boost: Niko's proposal to create a team for traits, polonius, etc. (see Zulip Topic)
Oh, I was about to write that
Thanks!
also, we did see a bump in activity in #new members > compiler 2022 after the 2022 ambitions post. It would be good for everyone interested in helping new comers to keep your eyes on that
Also, we're going to try to restart the traits meetings, if you're interested, please fill out the when2meet

(I don't know how best to try to continue to drive interest there, though. I'm realizing that an inside-rust blog post, like a newspaper article, isn't always going to get recirculated amongst the population...)

Jack Huey said:

Also, we're going to try to restart the traits meetings, if you're interested, please fill out the when2meet

link

anyway we'll just have to see if anything comes of that. The best thing is to drive progress forward, and then advertise that progress, the way that @lqd and @nnethercote have been with their performance roadmap work.
anyway, on with meeting agenda

MCPs/FCPs

  • New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 8 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 5 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "Dealing with type/const ambiguities" compiler-team#480 (last review activity: about 41 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize native library modifier syntax and the whole-archive modifier specifically" rust#93901

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "allow arbitrary inherent impls in the standard library" compiler-team#487

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Simplify rustc_codegen_llvm::debuginfo::metadata" compiler-team#482
    • "Round-tripping hygienic ident serialization" compiler-team#485

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Check if enum from foreign crate has any non exhaustive variants when attempting a cast" rust#92744
    • "Stabilize #[cfg(panic = "...")]" rust#93658
    • "Remove the everybody loops pass" rust#93913

WG checkins

(sounds like each WG this week either has nothing to report or is not available to generate a report. Which is fine.)

Backport nominations

T-compiler beta / T-compiler stable

• "Check method input expressions once" rust#94438
    • PR opened by @Michael Goulet (compiler-errors)
    • PR is merged
    • nominated for backport by @Noah Lev
    • backport pending resolution of rust#94516
An ICE fix but unclear to me if it was a regression.
the comment thread indicates that it canot be backported on its own

camelid wrote:

Actually, this PR seems to have led to an ICE of its own, so it probably doesn't make sense to backport it: #94516
but also, if this isn't a regression, I think I'm @nagisa that this can ride the trains?
It would be good to figure this out, but I'm going to vote :stop: entirely based on the fact that this is not currently backportable.
It is a regression.
Is it not a regression from stable? It's due to a diagnostic that got introduced recently.
I think we should vote on the full set of the necessary PRs to backport.
right
Agree to that though, and I need to still fix it
I was more figuring, if we would not backport this in any case, then we could just eagerly decline rather than revisiting later
but I am okay with just leaving it beta-backport-nominated

Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) said:

Is it not a regression from stable? It's due to a diagnostic that got introduced recently.

Yeah, I wasn't sure since issues nor the PR have the regression label.

tm said:

It is a regression.

it would be useful if the issues were tagged
yes, what @nagisa said
so, okay: We'll leave this nominated, and someone should figure out where this regressed, and update labels accordingly.
If someone volunteers to do that, great. Otherwise it can fallback to me
lets move along

• "backport fix for #94502" rust#94552
    • @lcnr authored PR, merge is in beta branch
    • @oli nominated for beta backport
seems like it is fixing a serious crater discovered ICE.
/me goes down rabbit hole of figuring out what end-effect of tainted_by_errors is
yea, the fix is also just avoiding the ICE, no functional changes, so seems fairly low danger
the tainted field is used to skip const eval if the MIR is erroneous
otherwise we keep getting ICEs in MIR interpret
I see, okay
backport approved
• No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs S-waiting-on-team for T-compiler

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Support #[global_allocator] without the allocator shim" rust#86844 (last review activity: 4 months ago)
    • @pnkfelix self-assigned in a previous meeting
ah crap, my oversight
added to personal list of action items

• "remove obligation dedup from impl_or_trait_obligations" rust#84944 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • cc: @Aaron Hill
(skimming comment thread on PR)
Yeah, just waiting on @Aaron Hill here. If they hadn't raised concerns, I would have already r+ed
I guess we could be prudent and just do a crater run
will crater runs catch performance issues?
e.g. does crater time out if something blows up incredibly?
that's...a good question
@simulacrum do you know the answer to ^ ?
no they will not
okay, so in terms of the most recent concerns that @Aaron Hill registered, I don't think crater will help.
I would have to assume we can't rely on crater to catch these kinds of issues since it didn't flag releases with some significant regressions in the past.
but I also think they may have been addressed by rust-lang/rustc-perf#1124 ?
It's worth noting: the blowup this code was originally added for has a benchmark
I think
so I personally think we just just r+ this.

pnkfelix said:

e.g. does crater time out if something blows up incredibly?

how hard would it be to make crater do so?
seems like a nice little side project
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/185
my vote is just to r+
yeah lets do that. @Jack Huey you have my blessing to do so. :)

• "Fix late-bound ICE" rust#92289 (last review activity: about 51 days ago)
    • reviewed by @Wesley Wiser
    • asking @Esteban Küber for a second look (see review)
Lets wait and see if @Esteban Küber responds to @Wesley Wiser 's question

• "add #[must_use] to functions of slice and its iterators." rust#92853 (last review activity: about 48 days ago)
    • rustbot assigned reviewer @Josh Triplett and label T-compiler
    • However: PR author references issue rust#89692, which is T-libs-api
    • reroll assignee? Change team?
was this a misclassification by rustbot ?
seems entirely T-libs-api to me.
relabelling
weird, how did that get labeled T-compiler...

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 1 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 68 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 47 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 0 P-high, 0 P-medium, 2 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 1 P-critical, 43 P-high, 84 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "optimized i686 fails primal-sieve tests" rust#94032
    • mentioned last week (see message)
    • decision to demote priority pushed to this meeting
this has an LLVM patch
but oh no https://reviews.llvm.org/D120330 is marked as Abandoned ...
This looks p-critical to me
hmm wait so there is activity in https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/53990 from 7 hours ago
ah https://reviews.llvm.org/D120800 is the one that landed, maybe ?:
or no, hasn't landed yet?
or it did land but its getting discussed because it regressed code size ... ?
okay so its clear this is actively being worked on, that's good
https://reviews.llvm.org/D120800 was merged.
Do we downgrade to P-high?
Given that the fix is in the works
right but there are comments on https://reviews.llvm.org/D120800 from last night where the LLVM devs are debating what path to take
And we already decided it's not release-blocking
https://reviews.llvm.org/rG6fde0439512580df793f3f48f95757b47de40d2b still might get reverted or something, but it hasn't been yet.
mmm. I want to make sure we backport the LLVM fix once it happens
(i.e. once it seems like they've settled on a plan; I'm hesistant to back port the one that landed since I'm worried it might get reverted.)
if we downgrade this to P-high, I'm a little nervous we wont prioritize the backport
on the other hand, I dislike classifying things as P-critical that aren't true release blockers
Need some triagebot feature to ping us in like 2 weeks time to check on this
heh
Lets leave it as P-critical
its okay to revisit on weekly basis in short term
we can easily downgrade it later if it becomes clear that its not buying us anything

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

perf triage logs for 2022-03-01

A relatively noisy week in performance measurements, particularly on the
externs incremental benchmark. Based on the timing of the first noise, this
seems to be due to [#93839], which makes me suspect this is related to PGO or
inlining decisions of some kind. [#94373] might help.

Overall a relatively unchanged to slightly good week, with no outright regressions and most
changes relatively small.

[#93839]: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/93839
[#94373]: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/94373

Triage done by @simulacrum.
Revision range: 1204400ab8da9830f6f77a5e40e7ad3ea459676a..f0c4da49983aa699f715caf681e3154b445fb60b

0 Regressions, 5 Improvements, 6 Mixed; 2 of them in rollups
43 comparisons made in total
(I should file a zulip bug that it cannot handle markdown of the above form in the context of a single comment)

Regressions

  • No regressions this week.

Improvements

  • At opt-level=0, apply only ABI-affecting attributes to functions #94127
  • Make TLS __getit #[inline(always)] on non-Windows #94373
  • Avoid query cache sharding code in single-threaded mode #94084
  • Apply noundef attribute to all scalar types which do not permit raw init #94157
  • rustc_errors: let DiagnosticBuilder::emit return a "guarantee of emission". #93368

Mixed

Back more metadata using per-query tables #94129

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.8%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -0.6%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: -0.5%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -1.0% on full builds of wf-projection-stress-65510 doc
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 0.9% on incr-unchanged builds of externs opt

Rollup of 9 pull requests #94333

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.8%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -5.9%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: -3.3%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -14.4% on incr-unchanged builds of encoding check
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 1.1% on incr-patched: println builds of cargo opt

Use undef for (some) partially-uninit constants #94130

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.7%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -1.9%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: -0.1%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -2.9% on full builds of ctfe-stress-4 opt
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 0.9% on incr-unchanged builds of externs opt

Caching the stable hash of Ty within itself #94299

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.9%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -1.2%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: -1.0%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -9.6% on incr-unchanged builds of clap-rs check
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 1.3% on incr-full builds of deeply-nested check

Revert "Auto merge of #92419 - erikdesjardins:coldland, r=nagisa" #94402

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.7%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -1.7%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: 0.5%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -3.8% on full builds of ripgrep opt
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 3.3% on full builds of syn opt

Rollup of 7 pull requests #94469

  • Arithmetic mean of relevant regressions: 0.3%
  • Arithmetic mean of relevant improvements: -0.8%
  • Arithmetic mean of all relevant changes: 0.0%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -0.9% on incr-unchanged builds of externs debug
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 0.3% on full builds of await-call-tree doc
  • Regression across multiple doc benchmarks.
aside: "arithmetic mean of percentage changes" -- aren't you supposed to use geometric mean when you're looking at %changes?
for % changes arithmetic mean seems fine? because the numbers are already normalized?
oh maybe
well, I think my goto example is when you think about how things scale
if I have one change that has a doubling effect: 2x
and another that has a halving effect: 1/2x
it is not good to use the arithmetic mean to model their net effect
but I'm not sure if that example works here
well, if nothing else, the geometric mean of { 2, 0.5 } is indeed 1
okay, on to nominated issues

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "Stabilize guaranteed compile time evaluation of unnamed constant items" rust#93838
    • nominated by @pnkfelix to ensure T-compiler people are ok
basically this PR issue is someone proposing that we document the current behavior and stably guarantee that we're going to stick to it
does anyone here think that this deserves an outright team FCP ?
sounds good to me -- it's what I would expect/hope the compiler does
(I suspect a full FCP not necessary)

oh, and I remember now; this note from me:

if firmer language is required to be checked against the rust-lang/reference, then we need to check that nominations there show up on the T-compiler agenda.

was, as much as anything, a note that our current T-compiler agenda, AFAIK, does not include nominations for our team in the rust-lang/reference
but also, https://github.com/rust-lang/reference does not have per-team nomination labels
T-compiler doesn't even exist as a label on that repo. :laughing:
um, so, yeah
I think we are doing a collective "sounds fine" on issue #93838

next up:

  • "process: release procedure only runs crater on nightly->beta cut" rust#94266
    • nominated by @pnkfelix for T-compiler discussion
I'd appreciate everyone to read that issue

the high order bit is the last sentence:

We probably should also include time in the project planning to allow for "one last crater run", and then use very strict backport criteria for anything that lands after that point.
I probably should bring this up with the release team at their meeting tomorrow
I'm wondering sometimes if releasing every 6 weeks is too often
anyway, I think at this point this is more of a general announcement / knowledge share with our team
@mw if you release less often, then there's even more pressure to get everything right when you do release
because you know people will be stuck with it for longer
true
from talking to @simulacrum
I'm just wondering if the release cadence is in balance with how long it takes to do a crater run
it is true that crater runs take time
or land fixes
but the big cost for crater, according to @simulacrum
is human beings to review the results
I think that's a really interesting thing to dig into
e.g.: If we invested some effort in making crater's output better
then maybe it wouldn't be so arduous for humans to review?
just a thought
sounds promising
oh, and finally

RFC

  • "New Cargo and Rust options to support embedding Natvis into a PDB" rfcs#3191
    • mentioned last week
exciting

as @Wesley Wiser said last week:

Now would be a good time for other compiler team members to take a look before we start an FCP to merge.
I'm curious: when we have to backport a fix, when was the original issue introduced in the cycle? I.e. was it near the end when there was less testing?

For a rough judge: I filed bugs for https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/94345 from 5:52 to 6:33, implying roughly 1 hour of crater triage time, and probably roughly half that for the rustdoc run (due to complete in a few days).
@Jack Huey I'm not sure I understand your question?
Hmm, trying to think how to rephrase

simulacrum said:

For a rough judge: I filed bugs for https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/94345 from 5:52 to 6:33, implying roughly 1 hour of crater triage time, and probably roughly half that for the rustdoc run (due to complete in a few days).

as in, it took you roughly 40 minutes of human labor, and you're probably one of the most expert at reviewing the output, right?
I would estimate 1 hour -- I typically don't file the first bug immediately -- but yes, to both.
I guess, my line of thought was: Could we run the crater run earlier than the beta cut? Maybe in the last week.
ah I see
Or a crater run
But, if most of the bugs that we end up needing to backport are in that last week, it doesn't make sense
the ideal would be continuous crater runs. but that definitely requires human dedication, or else its pointless.
So, is there anything we can do to lessen the human workload of crater triage?
ah, that was brought up
yeah exactly
I could imagine we could have continuous low-priority crater runs of some small subset of crates
its something we should think about. we might benefit from reviewing how @simulacrum does triage
but, not sure that really helps
@simulacrum would you be willing to take a screencast of the hour you spend doing it?
A middle point is weekly runs iff there have been backports, and having a view for the diff between crater runs
maybe! I've thought about something like that
Anyway, our hour is up! Thank you so much to all of @T-compiler/meeting for attending! Great meeting y'all, its always great when we get through the rote stuff and have time to discuss nominatinos
also: Make sure to put in proposals for this steering cycle!
planning meeting tomorrow at 2022-03-04T10:00:00-05:00 !

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/EewyTLZXQpmtfaH633GU-A?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry
  • WG-traits by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey
Now would be a good time to start transitioning some of the WG-traits checkins to more initiative focused
Let's start by leaving WG-traits in, but +generic-associated-types-initiative +impl-trait-initiative
The wg-traits checkin can be for general things and anything not covered by individual initiative checkins

ok. So, I can add to the rotation these two subteams, iiuc:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/project-generic-associated-types.toml
  • https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/project-impl-trait.toml

Also, as I see there seems to be no specific Zulip streams, I think I can simply mention the leads, something such as:

  • WG-traits (impl trait) @_nikomatsakis
  • WG-traits (generic associated types) @_**Jack Huey**
GATs would be me. Impl trait, probably @oli
#t-compiler/etc/opaque-types is probably the closest for impl trait. But wg-traits is fine

pnkfelix said:

  • "add #[must_use] to functions of slice and its iterators." rust#92853 (last review activity: about 48 days ago)
    • rustbot assigned reviewer Josh Triplett and label T-compiler
    • However: PR author references issue rust#89692, which is T-libs-api
    • reroll assignee? Change team?

Not sure why this was T-compiler rather than T-libs-api, but in any case, I've reviewed it and r+ed it now.

pnkfelix said:

planning meeting tomorrow at 2022-03-04T10:00:00-05:00 !

This was incorrect. Today's steering meeting is a backlog bonanza. The planning meeting will be on 2022-03-11T10:00:00-05:00
